Module nvim.cmake_file_api

CMake File API client implementation for Neovim.

CMake provides a file-based API that clients may use to get semantic information about the buildsystems CMake generates. Clients may use the API by writing query files to a specific location in a build tree to request zero or more Object Kinds. When CMake generates the buildsystem in that build tree it will read the query files and write reply files for the client to read.

All in one

write_configure_read (build, function[, callback]) Write a query for everything, configure CMake, and read the reply of the CMake File API.

Queries

write_query (build[, callback]) Write a query for everything to the CMake File API.
write_codemodel_query (build[, version[, callback]]) Write a "codemodel" query for the CMake File API.
write_cache_query (build[, version[, callback]]) Write a "cache" query for the CMake File API.
write_cmake_files_query (build[, version[, callback]]) Write a "cmakeFiles" query for the CMake File API.
write_toolchains_query (build[, version[, callback]]) Write a "toolchains" query for the CMake File API.
write_shared_stateless_query (build, kind, version[, callback]) Write a shared stateless query for the CMake File API.
write_client_stateless_query (build, kind, version[, callback]) Write a client stateless query for the CMake File API.
write_client_stateful_query (build, query[, callback]) Write a query for the CMake File API.

Reply

read_reply (build[, callback]) Read a reply from the CMake File API (it rhymes!).

All in one

Methods that write a CMake File API query, run a method that generates a buildsystem and read the reply of the CMake File API.
write_configure_read (build, function[, callback])
Write a query for everything, configure CMake, and read the reply of the CMake File API.

This is the best way to start using the CMake File API if you want to get started quickly because it enables you to extract all information the CMake File API can give you.

If you already know how the CMake File API works then this writes "codemodel" , "cache", "cmakeFiles", and "tooolchains" stateless client queries and reads their replies after the configure step is done. The versions of these queries are 2, 2, 1, and 1 respectively.

Links:

    CMake File API documentation

Parameters:

  • build string The build directory of the to be generated buildsystem.
  • function configure The method to call after writing the query to generate the buildsystem. If a callback parameter is provided this method should take a callback parameter, so it can configure CMake asynchronously and call the callback. If a callback is not provided, this method will be called without parameters and everything wiill be executed synchronously.
  • callback function, string or nil It can be a Lua function, a Vim command string, or nil. If not nil, the method will run asynchronously and call the callback upon completion with the reply object as the single arugument. Otherwise, it will run synchronously and return the reply object normally. (optional)

Queries

methods to call before configuring CMake in order to instruct it what data to generate using the API.
write_query (build[, callback])
Write a query for everything to the CMake File API.

This is the best way to start using the CMake File API if you want to get started quickly and you don't want to use the "all-in-one" write_configure_read method.

If you already know how the CMake File API works then this writes "codemodel" , "cache", "cmakeFiles", and "tooolchains" stateless client queries. The versions of these queries are 2, 2, 1, and 1 respectively.

Links:

    CMake File API documentation

Parameters:

  • build string The build directory of the to be generated buildsystem.
  • callback function, string or nil It can be a Lua function, a Vim command string, or nil. If not nil, the method will run asynchronously and call the callback upon completion. Otherwise, it will run synchronously. (optional)
write_codemodel_query (build[, version[, callback]])
Write a "codemodel" query for the CMake File API.

The "codemodel" query can be used to extract information about directories, configurations and targets of the generated build system.

More technically, it writes a stateless client "codemodel" query of version 2.

Links:

    "codemodel" object kind documentation

Parameters:

  • build string The build directory of the to be generated buildsystem.
  • version number, string or nil The major version of the "codemodel" query to send. Valid values are: 1 and 2. If nil, 2 is used. (optional)
  • callback function, string or nil It can be a Lua function, a Vim command string, or nil. If not nil, the method will run asynchronously and call the callback upon completion. Otherwise, it will run synchronously. (optional)
write_cache_query (build[, version[, callback]])
Write a "cache" query for the CMake File API.

The "cache" query can be used to extract information about the CMake cache.

More technically, it writes a stateless client "cache" query of version 2.

Links:

    "cache" object kind documentation

Parameters:

  • build string The build directory of the to be generated buildsystem.
  • version number, string or nil The major version of the "cache" query to send. Valid values are: 1 and 2. If nil, 2 is used. (optional)
  • callback function, string or nil It can be a Lua function, a Vim command string, or nil. If not nil, the method will run asynchronously and call the callback upon completion. Otherwise, it will run synchronously. (optional)
write_cmake_files_query (build[, version[, callback]])
Write a "cmakeFiles" query for the CMake File API.

The "cmakeFiles" query can be used to extract information about the generated CMake build system files.

More technically, it writes a stateless client "cmakeFiles" query of version 1.

Links:

    "cmakeFiles" object kind documentation

Parameters:

  • build string The build directory of the to be generated buildsystem.
  • version number, string or nil The major version of the "cmakeFiles" query to send. Valid values are: 1 and 2. If nil, 1 is used. (optional)
  • callback function, string or nil It can be a Lua function, a Vim command string, or nil. If not nil, the method will run asynchronously and call the callback upon completion. Otherwise, it will run synchronously. (optional)
write_toolchains_query (build[, version[, callback]])
Write a "toolchains" query for the CMake File API.

The "toolchains" query can be used to extract information about directories, configurations and targets of the generated build system.

More technically, it writes a stateless client "toolchains" query of version 2.

Links:

    "toolchains" object kind documentation

Parameters:

  • build string The build directory of the to be generated buildsystem.
  • version number, string or nil The major version of the "toolchains" query to send. Valid values are: 1 and 2. If nil, 1 is used. (optional)
  • callback function, string or nil It can be a Lua function, a Vim command string, or nil. If not nil, the method will run asynchronously and call the callback upon completion. Otherwise, it will run synchronously. (optional)
write_shared_stateless_query (build, kind, version[, callback])
Write a shared stateless query for the CMake File API.

The query will be shared with other clients such as IDE's and editors and is therefore not recommended for use, but is implemented for the sake of completion of the API. See the shared stateless query documentation for more info.

Links:

  • Shared stateless query documentation
  • Object kind documentation

Parameters:

  • build string The build directory of the to be generated buildsystem.
  • kind string The kind of query to send. Valid values are: "codemodel", "cache", "cmakeFiles", and "tkolchains". See the object kind documentation for more info.
  • version number or string The major version of the query kind to send. Valid values depend on the query kind. See the CMake File API documentation for more info.
  • callback function, string or nil It can be a Lua function, a Vim command string, or nil. If not nil, the method will run asynchronously and call the callback upon completion. Otherwise, it will run synchronously. (optional)
write_client_stateless_query (build, kind, version[, callback])
Write a client stateless query for the CMake File API.

The query won't be shared with other clients such as IDE's and editors. See the client stateless query documentation for more info.

Links:

  • Client stateless query documentation
  • Object kind documentation

Parameters:

  • build string The build directory of the to be generated buildsystem.
  • kind string The kind of query to send. Valid values are: "codemodel", "cache", "cmakeFiles", and "toolchains". See the object kind documentation for more info.
  • version number or string The major version of the query kind to send. Valid values depend on the query kind. See the CMake File API documentation for more info.
  • callback function, string or nil It can be a Lua function, a Vim command string, or nil. If not nil, the method will run asynchronously and call the callback upon completion. Otherwise, it will run synchronously. (optional)
write_client_stateful_query (build, query[, callback])
Write a query for the CMake File API.

The query will be shared with other clients such as IDE's and editors. See the shared stateless query documentation for more info.

Links:

  • Client stateful query documentation
  • Object kind documentation

Parameters:

  • build string The build directory of the to be generated buildsystem.
  • query table The query to send to the CMake File API. Reqd the client statefull query documentation for more info.
  • callback function, string or nil It can be a Lua function, a Vim command string, or nil. If not nil, the method will run asynchronously and call the callback upon completion. Otherwise, it will run synchronously. (optional)

Reply

Functions and classes to use after configuring CMake in order to read the reply of the API.
read_reply (build[, callback])
Read a reply from the CMake File API (it rhymes!).

See the reply index file documentation for more info.

Links:

    Reply index file documentation

Parameters:

  • build string The build directory of the generated buildsystem. It has to be an already existing directory on the filesystem.
  • callback function, string or nil It can be a Lua function, a Vim command string, or nil. If not nil, the method will run asynchronously and call the callback upon completion with the returned object as the single argument. Otherwise, it will run synchronously and return the object normally. (optional)

Returns:

    Returns an object represention the reply. All the fields of this type are the same as in the reply index file documentation except for special fields that have the key "jsonFile". These fields are not immediately loaded and are instead initialized as a lazy. Lazy objects have a path field and a load method which can run synchronously and asynchronously to retrieve the desired field as an object.

See also:

  • object
  • lazy

Class object

Reply object class.

Returned by the read_reply method. All the fields of this type are the same as in the reply index file documentation except for special fields that have the key "jsonFile". These fields are not immediately loaded and are instead initialized as a lazy. Lazy objects have a path field and a load method which can run synchronously and asynchronously to retrieve the desired field as a object.

object.is_object (value)
Check if a value is a object.

Parameters:

  • value Value to check against.

Returns:

    boolean Whether the value is an object.
object.new (path, data)
Create a new object.

Values of fields with the key "jsonFile" are going to be converted to lazy values.

Parameters:

  • path string Path to the JSON file from which this was read.
  • data table Data representing some values of the reply.

Returns:

    Constructed object.

Class lazy

Lazy object field class.

Values of fields with the key "jsonFiles" of API replies are converted to lazy values that can be loaded synchronously or asynchronously with the lazy:load method into an object.

lazy.is_lazy (value)
Check if a value is a lazy.

Parameters:

  • value Value to check against.

Returns:

    boolean Whether the value is a lazy.
lazy.new (path)
Create a new lazy The lazy can be loaded later into an object with the lazy:load method.

Parameters:

  • path string Path to the JSON file from which this will be read.

Returns:

    Constructed lazy.
lazy:load ([callback])
Load a lazy.

Load a lazy int an object synchronously or asynchronously.

Parameters:

  • callback function, string or nil It can be a Lua function, a Vim command string, or nil. If not nil, the method will run asynchronously and call the callback upon completion. Otherwise, it will run synchronously. (optional)

Returns:

    Loaded lazy as an object.
